content: The Act is titled the "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006". It pertains to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006 defines key terms related to the Blunt Reservoir feature, Pierre Canal feature, Commission, nonpreferential lease parcel, and preferential leaseholder. The Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006 defines terms like preferential leaseholder, preferential lease parcel, Secretary, State, and unleased parcel in relation to the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and the State of South Dakota may accept ownership of certain features and liabilities associated with them. The State of South Dakota may accept ownership of certain features and liabilities associated with expired easements, purchase options for preferential leaseholders, and outstanding oil, gas, mineral rights, permits, licenses, leases, and rights-of-way. Conveyances to the State are subject to reservations by the United States and conditions specified in the Act of May 19, 1948 for wildlife conservation purposes. Preferential leaseholders have the option to purchase the preferential lease parcel under specified terms. The value of the parcel determined under paragraph (4) minus ten percent of that value. Preferential leaseholders have the option to purchase the parcel with 10 percent down and the remainder paid over 30 years at 3 percent interest. If the parcel is under $10,000, it must be purchased on a cash basis. Leaseholders have 5 years to exercise the purchase option. The value of the parcel is based on its fair market value for agricultural purposes. The value of a preferential lease parcel is determined by its fair market value for agricultural purposes, less 25 percent. Disputes over the value are resolved according to federal regulations. If a leaseholder fails to purchase the parcel within the specified time, it may be conveyed to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will use land conveyed for wildlife habitat mitigation due to the Pick-Sloan project development. Proceeds from land sales will establish a trust fund for county taxes. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels to the Department for the same purpose. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will use land conveyed for wildlife habitat mitigation due to the Pick-Sloan project development. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands may allow land exchanges for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal. The priority for exchanges includes current lessees and adjoining landowners. The United States reserves a perpetual easement for water conveyance structures as a condition of land exchanges at Pierre Canal. The United States will not be liable for damages after conveying parcels, except for acts of negligence. The United States will not be liable for damages after conveying parcels, except for acts of negligence committed before the date of conveyance. No additional liability is added under the Federal Tort Claims Act. The Secretary will continue to lease parcels under existing terms until conveyance, and provide parcel descriptions to the State within 180 days of enactment. The Secretary will transfer archeological items to the South Dakota State Historical Society without cost. $750,000 is authorized for expenses, with additional funds for the Commission and State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks.
